qas.question: What was the Anglo-Norman language's final form?
Who identified themselves as French during the Hundred Years War?
What was absorbed into the Anglo-Norman language?
Who made fun of the Latin language?

context: Eventually, the Normans merged with the natives, combining languages and traditions. In the course of the Hundred Years' War, the <b1_0>Norman aristocracy<b1_0/> often identified themselves as English. The Anglo-Norman language became distinct from the Latin language, something that was the subject of some humour by <b3_0>Geoffrey Chaucer<b3_0/>. The Anglo-Norman language was eventually absorbed into the <b2_0>Anglo-Saxon<b2_0/> language of their subjects (see Old English) and influenced it, helping (along with the Norse language of the earlier Anglo-Norse settlers and the Latin used by the church) in the development of Middle English. It in turn evolved into <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2>Modern English<a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/>.
